Dying Light: The Beast Why You Should Play It

1. The Zombies Actually Get Torn Apart
The game delivers one of the most satisfying dismemberment systems ever made. Every hit reacts with flesh, bone, and blood effects that feel incredibly real, making it fun enough to keep you playing for hours.

2. Parkour Is Back and Better Than Ever
The signature parkour system returns stronger than before. Jumping from rooftop to rooftop, dodging zombies, and feeling that rush of adrenaline is still an absolute thrill.

3. The Storytelling Is Much Stronger Than DL2
Compared to Dying Light 2, this game tells its story in a more focused, emotional, and dynamic way. The mission flow feels natural, and character motivations are much more believable.

4. The Volatiles Are Back
The most terrifying enemies of the series make a comeback. Going out at night still requires courage, and the tension they create gives the game a chilling atmosphere.

5. The Graphics Are Beautiful
Lighting, shadows, and environment details all look fantastic by modern standards. Night scenes, in particular, are a true visual feast.

Cons

1. The Vehicle System Feels Unnecessary
You almost never need to use a car. The parkour system is already so fun and fluid that driving feels like a distraction from the core gameplay.

2. The Skill System Is Too Shallow
With a level cap of only 15 and very few skill branches, the progression system feels limited and does not provide long-term satisfaction.

Dying Light The Beast stands out with its atmosphere, dismemberment mechanics, and terrifying night sequences. Despite a few small flaws, it remains a must-play for anyone who loves zombie action games.

I've been playing Dying Light since 2015. The first game is one of my favourite games of all time, and even with it being a decade old it is still the best game of the 3. Tell me I'm blinded by nostalgia, I don't care because I've followed the journey nearly every step of the way. I put so much time into DL1 only to be massively disappointed by DL2. DL the Beast is a huge upgrade from DL2. 

Yes The Beast runs on the same engine but overall it feels smoother and less janky than the second game. The only issues I have are with combat, the npcs and UI. After exiting the weapon wheel, your character will be stuck in the direction of which key you are pressing until you release and repress the key. 

The human npcs dodge a bit too much. It wouldn't bother me if it actually made sense, they dodge backwards when my weapon is clearly hitting them, if they blocked or actually moved away from my attack then it would be better...also the grenade spam they do when you're driving near them is pretty annoying.

Then there's the charged kick which does absolutely nothing to stop enemies below you, whether they're on the ground or climbing a building to get to you, you can only use the charged kick if the zombie/npc is standing on the same level as you otherwise you will miss. Please fix all this it's been like this since release ^^^



Now on to the things that Techland did right. The story was awesome. And it felt great to play as Kyle Crane again. The 3rd person cutscenes were implemented quite well, there weren't too many and they picked the right moments to switch back to 1st person. It was also good to see Kyle from another perspective where you can actually see his emotions on display. There are no boring missions and even the side missions were quality, some of them even felt like they were from DL1. The atmosphere is perfect. It has the ambience from the first game, the soundtracks are great and they absolutely nailed the horror aspect.  The behaviour of the infected is terrifying and I love that they respond to the torch shining on them. They can sneak up on you, wait for you behind corners and sometimes they just stare you down...creepy af. It also looks like they upped the gore a little bit from DL2. Though nothing beats the first games gore system.

The parkour flow is great, sometimes you can get stuck on small objects in the environment but it's a very minor issue. I have seen a lot of people complaining about parkour, unlike DL2 The Beast actually feels like a zombie game with parkour, not the other way around. DL2 parkour was too easy, too many parkour paths where it literally paves the way for you. 

It could be due to how small the map is but the zombies are always looking to grab you, which I actually like because it makes them more of a threat. Plus that wont matter when legend levels and NG+ arrives because most zombies will be 1-2 hit kill. There is a lot of weight behind each swing, when you miss you really pay for it and when you hit an enemy you can feel how much damage you are doing. It feels more gritty and less like a superhero game than DL2. Though Kyle is stronger than Aiden, he feels more realistic to control, more like a human and less like a weightless monkey jumping from rooftop to rooftop.


There are a lot of improvements to make but in comparison to DL2 this game is a masterpiece. Considering this was only released in September I am very impressed with it's current state. Would give it 8.5/10.

Things I would like to see in DL the Beast:


*Occasionally slow down time/X ray on critical hits and kills
*Stab/lunging stab animation for knives
*Overhand attack when facing down with fists or melees.
*OG block charge animation from the first game where it actually knocks zombies over.
*Harder dark zones in the day (volatiles included)
*More voicelines for hostile npcs, and survivors in the town hall.
*More shops
*Turbo boost on cars, (to throw volatiles off like in the following)
*More takedowns/executions (currently repetitive even after update)
*Maybe the Paraglider from DL2
*Future DLC Missions or content
*Hypermode event/Super crane
*More volatile screams in chase and mid attack
*OG screeching noise to volatiles falling from high places
*More OG viral screams when drawn to loud noises
*fully body OG gore system

The thing that impresses me most about Techland is their ability to listen to fans and the Dying Light community to improve their games. Thank you Techland for this banger of a game.

First off I would like to be entirely clear here. Most of these negative reviews are bullocks. I'm not going to lie, their are a few misses here with this game but they are few and far between. The biggest one in my personal opinion is really just the writing. The story while it isn't bad at all is a bit cliche. It is a pretty typical big bad hurt you go get revenge story. The big bad being the Baron who I do agree doesn't get enough spotlight time. I genuinely love what we have with the Baron though. And yes what ends up happening with the Baron when you finally get there. Is on the less than savory side of things. Still they genuinely wanted to make you hate him and feel resentment towards him. Could have been wrote slightly better and that's entirely true. We got what we have here though and it still works just as fine. 

Lets get right into the game play though. Kyle Crane is back Roger Craig Smith the absolute mad lad is back voicing him and his voice is a treasure. He delivers with every line and he is back with a vengeance. Kyle Crane as we should all know by now is half man, half beast. They make it so well known in this game. You are a power house. Between the incredible combat of bashing, slashing, and shooting. And the ability to activate your beast mode going hand to hand ripping zombies into little pieces. Punching their heads clean off their shoulders. The combat feels GREAT. I can't tell you how many times I have been tickled by just how visceral the combat feels. The sounds, the incredible feeling of how smooth each strike feels against every walking corpse in your wake. Smacking a zombie so hard you blow its bottom jaw clean off. Splitting them completely in two with a solid crunchy swing. They sugar coated this combat with so many cool details. All the new abilities and returning ones feel great. They are weighty and not as floaty as the second but feel just as good as they did in the first game. Windmill my least favorite skill in the first game. Is my absolute favorite group clearing tool in this one. The skill tree is not as complex in here, but will most likely soon change with the introduction of the legends skills. What we have here though is a mix of some new mostly returning but improved skills. Then all of the skills Kyle had in the first are here. Just oriented a little different in the skill tree. They are also given to you slowly while leveling Kyle. The guns in the game while being hard to find significant amounts of ammo for are super fun. The human enemies aren't as crazy as the first games but just as dangerous. Usually carrying guns that will significantly hurt you if you aren't being smart around them. They pay attention to your cues very well. If you have a gun and they don't they will surrender now. Was not a feature at launch but due to fans bringing it up it has returned. If you are fighting them and have a fire arm. They will communicate and push you if they catch you reloading. They truthfully feel alive capable of figuring you out and pressuring you. Whether it be grouping up on you, or finding different angles to shoot you from. These bandits, and the Barons soldiers are out to get you. They will too if you don't deal with them quickly. Aside from them the typical mutations and dangerous zombies have returned. This time with a few different looks, and unique boss versions of them too. Each of them being a different form of threat. Whether hitting you with bile from a distance, lunging and leaping at you from large distances. Or the massive tank muscle monsters ready to run you down and pancake you. They all feel great to fight and should be a challenge for new players. That being said if you played the first or second game you know what you are getting into with them. You just have new tools and abilities to crush them. Each of these enemies also have unique ways to execute them too. Beast mode lets you really show them who is boss with a very well animated execution. You can even execute normal zombies in human form. All with great and gruesome glory kills basically. Like I said this game is a power trip. If you like being a badass zombie stomping menace. You will enjoy the combat here.

Of course this is a dying light game. So you know you're going to be climbing buildings and jumping across rooftops. That being said this game definitely can feel a little less parkour saturated then the rest. This is a country side town with somewhat smaller buildings and less of them than the other two games. I don't understand the complaints about it though. Yes you are running around or driving a lot. Their is still a hefty amount of parkour and movement here though. It's not like the game is completely void of free running and parkour. You will be sent out to climb buildings and towers that most people would not dare to ascend. It doesn't feel repetitive or lackluster though. Plus this environment while being way more rural than the first two games is absolutely alive and breathtaking. The world here is beautiful. It fits the apocalyptic vibe that a good zombie slasher should have. It genuinely suites this type of game. Even if you aren't climbing and jumping around like the first two. It's open and vast in the country. If you go out at night and are will-nilly running around and get caught. You do not have many place to run to. You signed your own death warrant going into the open fields with volatiles. The volatiles are the one few special infected that are on your level in lethality. They will destroy you if you also don't use your head around them. You gotta think quick and move quicker. That being said it is still oh so satisfying to pummel a group of volatiles. It is entirely possible to fight back against them. It is for sure a challenge though.

I am not the best at reviewing games and honestly who cares about my opinion anyways. But I will stick my neck out for Techland. I have loved Dying Light since I saw the first game announced. I still have my cheap plastic volatile mask from the announcement of the first game mounted on my wall. I love these games. I am a fan and will remain as one until Techland does something to change that. With that being said though I am incredibly happy with how much they have been listening to the fan base. This game ran very well for me at launch. Wasn't flawless for sure and I have a rig that was built in 2019. Still the game ran great and looks incredible. With recent updates though I do not even get the occasional hiccups I used to. And I know for a fact it will only get better as time goes on. Also this game was supposed to be DLC for Dying Light 2. Then they decided to release it as a standalone game. PLUS if you had the Ultimate edition of the second game they gave The Beast to you for free! Though I did pay for my copy and had no problem with that at all. Name one game dev that would ever do that in today's day and age? This game is my game of the year for 2025 and should set an example to the many greedy AAA game devs of today. Techland you kicked ass here. You showed us that you listen, care, and want to make quality games. Thank you Techland. You all have my heart.

[h1] Two steps forward, three back. [/h1]

I'll first start by stating that I am mostly an ambivalent fan of the franchise. Zombie games ruled the landscape of 2012-2016, and Dying Light was the only exception that added anything to the stale formula that had grown old, stale and safe. The parkour, the grappling hook, Be The Zombie, and all of the other unique and special things made me both love and dislike the game. Until today, I would say DL was a great game for the time (Albeit, with its issues of the story, and the following, but that's for the past.)

10 years later, and the rather unexceptional release of DL2, we have finally arrived at Dying Light: The Beast, and with Crane back, it was the signal for a return to form for the franchise, with new mechanics, and a hopefully revamped story... Or so it was to be.

[h3] So how is it? [/h3]
Good-ish. Once again, Techland hit some marks, missed (this time a lot), and missed some hits so far off the mark you can't even score it. 

[h2] On the World (The Map) [/h2]
DL is a franchise that lives and dies through the parkour and movement mechanics. DL:TB does not compliment this at all. In fact, it's rather mediocre, sometimes even just bad. The Slums and Old Town of Harran perfectly complimented the mechanics of the first game, there was enough both to run, sprint, vault, wall run, ledge, perch, and climb on, without flat fields of nothing (until you reached Old Town, and even these were minor.) In TB, half of the map is literal countryside/suburbish areas. Only the Old Town of this game compliments the mechanics this franchise is best known for. Flat open fields of nothing but grass, hills, sometimes roads, a highway, and the occasional house or small building is not. This isn't as much of a problem by the first few hours of gameplay, but as soon as you get out of the Old Town and the quests of Town Hall and explore the rest of the map you realize that Techland has adopted the Ubisoft Open World model of dropping a few keypoints of interest/places to do quests in, and the rest of the world simply serves as the mandatary form of wasting your time by either having to run (or drive) your way hundreds of kilometers off in Narnia to do one specific thing of a quest, or to pick up one item. This is especially bad the second you start doing the quests for the Exiled, where they have you walk from the northernmost point of the map all the way down south for some quests. It's just clearly padding, and doesn't fit the style of the franchise whatsoever. On top of this, despite how big the map looks in the in game overlay, you'll soon realize that it's just split four ways into the Mountains/hills side of the South, the West of this games Old Town, the North of an industrial center, and the East of random homes, suburbs, and small forests. The rest of the map is unused, and just there to force you to do side missions, or hunt for specific trophies/mementos. It felt underwhelming, weak, and worst of all, just an excuse to extend the games low 16 hour campaign into more playtime. 

[h2] On the Gameplay (and The Beast) [/h2]
Expect the standard DL formula. Find random weapons from the environment, from dead guys, or from quests, use them till they break, fix em, or find a new shinier weapon to replace that weapon, or a blueprint that becomes your main weapon. Nothing of this was changed. I didn't mind this in DL, and I don't mind it either in TB, but if you were a person that hated that gimmick, then don't expect anything mindblowing here. You still have to hit a zombie a couple times, dash back to regen stamina, use a bandage, and all that, at least until you get legendary weapons, where the zombies mostly become pushovers that you can kill in two or three swings, and the tension of getting swarmed is gone. However, the gore and the actual feeling of getting that hit on the zombies is incredible. The gore is Dead Island 2 tier of good, maybe even better. You can knock off parts of skulls, mandibles, break bones clearly, rip intestines, etc. It is fantastically done, very satisfying to fight enemies. Missions are mostly the same. Talk to a person, said person bosses you around, Crane does it, walk 100km to go get to said item, walk back 100km to give back said item. Still busy work, and still nothing special. As for the elephant in the room, the Beast System is nothing revolutionary, but certainly something that helps the old combat being far more enjoyable. Crane essentially tweaks out, pulls his two guns, and punches zombies/tears them in half, and against some enemies (like the dudes with the rebar hammers, or the Charger guys) you get unique and special executions to finally put the pin cushions down. The main problem is that not enough was done to make unleashing the beast more than anything of an assistance (and against bosses, a crutch). Unleashing the Beast forces you into Melee, which in difficulties like Brutal, means you can easily die in one or two hits (such as fighting some bosses of this game, the Chimeras). While this would be an awesome power fantasy, it dies the second you realize you get nothing more than punching, a ground slam, or jumping up high and slamming back down(You can also charge run, but this doesn't do much, and you can also kick, but the kick is the same generic animation with more damage). You can use the environment against the world, but you can only lift rocks/engine blocks. This was honestly the biggest mood killer for me because it would have been awesome for Crane to be able to lift up zombies, toss them like rag dolls, or even just using said zombie as a weapon, or lifting cars, fridges, desks, etc. Limiting this to two things really kills the power fantasy when Demolishers can break the floor to launch rocks at you, and you can only really throw grandmas porch rocks in response or punch him until you can do the execution. You can also scream, but this does really nothing but force a few generic zombies to stand in place. Greatly missed opportunities.

[h2] On the Skilltree (and movement)[/h2]
Another of the games major L's is undeniably in the skill tree. The Level Cap in TB is 15, and while this wouldn't be a bad thing on its own, it is, when we compare what skills we get here versus in DL or even DL2. In TB, Crane kept almost all of his parkour abilities( Except being able to slide kick). The skills you have to unlock the rest of his movement (Vault Kicking, Rolling after dropping, the Dropkick) are all things that have been seen a thousand times already (and you even start with some, like Wall Running). In fact, for some reason, despite being "The Beast" Crane is rather slow and sluggish, (especially in Ledge Jumping, where you sometimes snap into a random ledge, or get richocheted up in the sky). The skill tree itself also clearly seems to be half done. Getting a blueprint for a flamethrower? Grenade Launcher? Grenades? Really? This by far has the smallest skill tree in the 3 games, and certainly the least rich one. It is probably unironically faster to just sprint normally than it is to waste your time trying to climb up unto rooftops and trying to lower yourself constantly from there. In terms of the Parkour, I would say this is the weakest of the three. DL2 had Aiden be a motorcycle, gliding, dashing, running everywhere. DL1 had you unable to even run without wasting stamina, forcing you to think where to go, where to run up to, and where to avoid enemies. In TB, you do it to explore, or to get away from volatiles. 

[h2] On the Story [/h2]
TLDR, because I'm running out of characters, The Baron is an TEMU version of Albert Wesker. Betrayals happen out of circumstance, not conviction. The fact that Crane can beat Volatiles with his bare hands and shoes, letting some twink belittle him is just character assassination in the worst form.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

I was overall mostly satisfied with the game. A lot changed, a lot could be better. Get it on a sale. 6/10

The game is OK, but I have very important problems with it, mainly:

* There is no incentive to go out at night. In older games, dark zones would be filled with loot, and would be more accessible at night, so I would wait for nights to go looting. In this game, the dark zones are the same day and night, have at most 3-4 screamers guarding it, and extremely easy to deal with. 2x exp at night is good sure, but it is not why players would go out at night. If there is no reward, only incentive would be to play for the scare element, which brings me to my second point: 

* Nights are harder but not scarier. The volatile spawn is so dense that it takes away the scary factor and it becomes a nuisiance. "Oh so the sun is down now, let's spawn 10 volatiles in the near area, so the player will HAVE TO play the game as we want." No, I liked the old stealth part of Dying Light at night, navigating through extreme danger while hearing the hisses of volatiles. And if I get caught, and the chase starts, it is the consequence of my failed stealth attempt, not because I am forced to do so. 

* The map was not built with parkour in mind. Castor Woods is pretty sure, but when you take Harran as the gold standart, where everywhere you go, you climb, roll, swing, jump or a mix in between, driving place to place in Castor Woods get boring quickly. Parkour only matters when you are in the city center, but Dying Light is parkour, no one plays Dying Light for the captivating story or the memorable characters, you play it because it is the game with parkour and zombies. 

I still remember the "Good night, good luck." trailers from the first Dying Light, and looking at The Beast now, the resemblance is there sure, but they are also so much different. Dying Light was a masterpiece, this game is just OK. I am giving a thumbs up because I like this franchise and want to see it get better, but devs, please take a step back and look at what makes this franchise "Dying Light".

Dying Light The Beast is the perfect Dying Light game. It combines all the best elements from the first two games and expands upon them, making them even better. It includes plenty of new and unique ideas too, all which are strong in execution. Techland took the feedback from the second game, and used it to truly craft the perfect Dying Light experience. This review will contain zero spoilers for story content. 

I will start off with my negatives for the game. These are short and not too inconsequential to the overall experience. I will get into nighttime later in the review, but the game unfortunately does have little incentive to play during night. There aren‚Äôt many missions in which you need to be out at night, and even the returning darkzones from DL2 can now be done during the day. There is a singular side quest which forces you out at night, and I wish there were more quests (story or not) which did this. While I did personally choose to venture out at night, you really don‚Äôt have to. I also wish the skill tree was bigger. Excluding the beast skills, the base skill tree is quite small and you start the game with a lot of skills preunlocked, and I would‚Äôve preferred if these were unlockable skills instead. The skills you do get to unlock are awesome, but I wish there was more to unlock. Finally, the dialogue can be a little rough, and cheesy at times. It doesn‚Äôt drag the story down thankfully, but some lines can be quite goofy at points.

Now for what I love about the game, which is pretty much everything else.

The night time, one of the most underwhelming parts of the second game, is perfect here in The Beast. It‚Äôs a shame only a few activities force you out at night, but besides this, Techland nailed night time horror. Being out at night is a death sentence, and feels terrifying. Volatiles are dangerous and deadly once again, being almost impossible to kill even within Beast mode. They feel like a true threat again, making going out at night dangerous like the first game. Being stealthy is key to avoiding chase, which can easily lead to death if not careful. Chases are also terrifying, having the most haunting and scary music, which builds up to become more tense as the chase progresses. The entire soundtrack is incredible. It has some of the best scores this franchise has seen, and I love nearly every bit of music Dying Light The Beast has.  

The combat feels satisfying again, especially with the improved gore system. Weapons feel satisfying to use, with heavy weapons feeling but also sounding heavier when you hit zombies or when just swinging them in general. Guns also are the best they have ever been in the franchise. They no longer feel like a get-out-of-jail free card nor do they feel tacked on. They‚Äôre well balanced and fun to use, and ammo being scarce forces you to always consider if using your gun is worth it. The physics also helps with making the combat feel enjoyable. Zombies react properly to being hit by different types of weapons, and it helps in making weapons feel unique and like they have distinctive ways they affect the zombies. As well as that, the ragdolls feel improved, making combat moves like the Dropkick feel fun to use again as zombies react more similarly to how they did in Dying Light 1. Combat is at its best in Dying Light The Beast. The added difficulty helps with this too. Zombies are truly dangerous this time, and everything is incredibly powerful. You cannot brute force fights. You have to be strategic in encounters. Whether you use your surroundings, lure zombies out of the pack one by one or use tools like moltovos, you have to always approach every encounter with care. Going in guns blazing will get you killed.

Beast Mode is also a concept introduced, where Kyle Crane enters a volatile state and can rip through enemies like paper. This is an incredibly fun feature, and adds to combat in a positive way. It charges through killing enemies or taking damage, and as you upgrade to give Kyle more combat moves and just make it more powerful overall, it becomes a chaotic and satisfying tool, one which you also have to utilize at the best times, as it can save you in difficult encounters, both outside and inside of combat.

Parkour is also amazing, taking the best parts of the first two games, and making them even better while improving on the weaker areas, and adding new interesting layers. The moves Crane can do are from Dying Light 2, but there is weight to everything. It no longer feels like you‚Äôre running in zero gravity, and it feels realistic while also keeping the more satisfying and enjoyable free-running from the second game. The game also brings back driving. It varies from The Following, but it‚Äôs equally as fun. You no longer have a singular buggy to upgrade, but multiple cars you can find in the open world. The driving is enjoyable and feels great, with fuel being a tricky resource to find, with you always having to keep on top of fuel for the next drive so you don‚Äôt end up having to run across open fields. Whether you parkour or drive across Castor Woods, you will have plenty to do and explore, as the map is incredibly rich in details, has plenty of content within it and looks gorgeous.

When it comes to the story, this is definitely the best story, being the most ambitious Techland has produced. While I won‚Äôt give spoilers, some of the characters you meet, the twists and reveals the game pulls as well as just some cool ideas they integrate, this story feels amazingly written, and was incredibly engaging. The side content was also surprising, being just as good as the main story, sometimes surpassing it at points. Certain side missions have great character development and emotional moments. They all feel unique and have purpose, containing amazing characters and moments which makes them incredibly memorable. The characters are also all amazing, and help elevate moments. Kyle Crane is amazing, and having him back is awesome. His arc and story feel satisfying, and Roger Craig Smith gives an amazing performance. This is Kyle Crane at his best. You can tell the years of experimentation have taken their toll on him, but he also still has the same charm he did back in Dying Light 1. The other characters you meet are also well developed and memorable too. These might be some of the best characters we‚Äôve met in the franchise.

Overall Dying Light: The Beast is without a doubt the best game in the franchise. It has the best parkour and combat in the series, the best and most engaging story, a killer soundtrack and nails the survival horror aspect. While it has certain flaws, they in no way shape or form drag the game down at all. While I am biased, and would personally give this game a 10/10, it is realistically a 9/10. A very strong 9/10 at that, and I would recommend anyone to play this game.

[b]Dying Light: The Beast[/b] feels like coming home. After the sprawl and ambition of the later titles, this entry‚Äîwhether you call it a massive expansion or a spin-off‚Äîsucceeds by scaling back the drama and focusing on what made the original Dying Light unforgettable: the grim atmosphere, the grounded parkour, and the sheer terror of night.

The biggest win here, bar none, is [b]the return of Kyle Crane[/b]. Hearing Roger Craig Smith's voice again as the main protagonist instantly re-establishes that classic Harran vibe. Crane's dialogue feels sharp, world-weary, and exactly like the guy we grew attached to. It's fantastic seeing his story continue, even if it's just for a focused new chapter. Fans have been asking for this, and Techland absolutely nailed the execution, respecting the legacy of the character.

What truly shines is the [b]return to a simpler, more personal story.[/b] Forget complex faction politics and sprawling city-spanning ethical dilemmas. The Beast strips the narrative down to a high-stakes survival mission with clear objectives and immediate threats. It's focused, fast-paced, and deeply atmospheric. It reminds you of the best parts of the original game: just a few survivors, a few volatile secrets, and the terrifying knowledge that the sun is going down.

The core gameplay loop is as addictive as ever. The movement feels tight, and the combat remains satisfyingly brutal. If you missed the pure, unadulterated zombie parkour experience with Crane leading the charge, do yourself a favor and pick this up. It's a love letter to the original fans.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Kyle Crane is back, and he's fantastic.

    [*]A simpler, tighter, and more focused narrative structure.

    [*]Classic Dying Light 1 atmosphere restored.

    [*]New enemy types (The Beast itself is terrifying).
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]

This game is very short compared to the other two games. In co-op with one other person it took us 26 hours to beat the main story, do most of the sidequests, and loot most of the darkzones/safehouses/etc on the map (all the ones with meaningful rewards). So honestly I can't recommend buying this game at full price, but if it's on sale for $30 or less and you like the franchise then it's just more of the same.

It's exactly the same as the other games where it's brutally hard at the start and then it gets easier as you play and level up, and it doesn't take very long at all to reach max level and max beast level (or at least get all of the perks that you want). There is quite a grind for materials but it's made easier by a certain armor set and weapon trinket that boost the amount of loot you get.

At least compared to the second game I felt like the looting in this one was less fun and much more one note. In the second game I enjoyed needing to parkour occasionally to find the high up crates, and I was actually excited to loot convoys because they gave things you needed. Dark zones were diverse and challenging and even just looting random houses was still rewarding (absolutely loved the rooftops with the honey and chamomile and whatnot too). 
In this game, all necessary loot can be obtained from dark zones, and all dark zones are more or less the exact same. There's only 2 enemy types that ever show up (one of them being the basic zombies) and they even reuse the same buildings for some of them. 

I feel the same way about the parkour as well. The second game had ledge grab sections, wall run sections, pole grab sections, rope sections, and sections where you needed to use your grappling hook and/or glider. This game has ledge grab sections... and that's pretty much it. There's no glider, and you do get a grappling hook but you can't climb up or down it like a rope and it's never necessary for the parkour. Not sure why they simplified the parkour to such an extreme, but 9 times out of 10 the hardest part is just finding where you need to start climbing because it's almost never marked (same if you're looking for a way to get into a building, we spent a lot of time just lost on where exactly to go just because there was always only a general area quest marker).

The combat is more or less the same as the other games, though they nerfed dropkicks quite a bit just by dramatically decreasing the amount of spike walls that are in the game (they still exist but are much less frequent). Outside of propane tanks they also reduced the amount of environmental weapons a lot, there's only one of them in this game (throwable only rebar spear) and it's rarely used. 

There are even less of the challenges in this game. The other games have ones for parkour, combat, and driving, but this game only has the driving ones (and at a certain point we could no longer do them because they would softlock our game every time we tried). 

As for the co-op, it was definitely one of the more annoying games that I've played co-op. Every player has to be Kyle Crane, and virtually every single action that's even remotely tied to a quest, no matter how small, requires that all players are standing within 5 feet of it. Doesn't matter if all you're doing is pressing a button, or opening one door, or picking up one item, all players have to be there to watch it happen. There are dozens and dozens of 1-2 second cutscenes where you just do one thing and then the cutscene ends, so many that my friend and I came up with a headcanon that we were two twin brothers who were pretending to be the same person so we could only do anything if we were both standing there one behind the other so it looked like we were just one guy. This means that if you ever want to split up for any reason, there's very few things that either of you are able to do by yourselves to actually progress your game in any way that won't just teleport the other player to you at one point or another. 

Probably my biggest complaint about the game (besides getting softlocked by the driving quest, map markers disappearing every session and occasionally getting stuck inside the map geometry) is that there's no fast travel. I guess the reason for this is that there are drivable cars you can use, and you get a grappling hook halfway through which helps as well. The cars are stupidly realistic, with the proper dashboard symbols popping up when you're low on gas / vehicle damaged / etc, a short pause whenever you use the horn because you have to move your hand over to it, and windshield wipers that turn on when the windshield is wet or dirty. However despite all this attention to detail, and cars being the main method of transportation, they lack any radio or boost functionality (not even in the driving challenges). No idea why as those seem like obvious things to have, ESPECIALLY if it's the main method of transportation since there's no fast travel. My honest opinion is that they didn't include fast travel in order to make the game take longer to complete, because it would have been ridiculously short if there was fast travel.

I played this game co-op with a friend the whole way, and it was probably the only reason I was able to finish it. The story opens up years after the events of the expansion of the first game, The Following, which in the canon ending, had Kyle infected and turned into a volatile. Whilst Beast Mode is cool, it becomes really underwhelming and by the half way point, basically worse than any of the weapons you find, which is a shame because it's one of the main selling points. The quests whilst the opening is strong, rapidly degrade having Kyle essentially do chores that he doesn't even want to do, which was a point in the first game, but he did it to help and also maintain his cover as he cared about everyone he met, whereas in this game, he openly says he doesn't care and it's not his problem but does it anyway. The objectives have you running like an insane person from one side of the map to the other, like a GTA Online mission which just adds a bunch of filler and wastes your time. Killing the Chimera's or the Bosses for Kyle to get extra powers is really cool the first few times, but it ends up becoming the same fights with there not really being any weaknesses to them other than just 'hit it till it dies', and watching the same finishing animation you've seen three times, and then you can get a new skill you're unlikely to use more than once.

The Baron, the main villain is just the typical, evil British dude who wears turtlenecks and kills people because it's shocking, which is what a lot of the last bit of the game is. The last two boss fights, being The Beast on normal difficulty has you get two shot whilst you're not allowed to hit him, and for some reason you aren't allowed to bring your own healing items or own weapons which is just difficulty balancing because the devs knew you'd be too powerful by this point so you need to be nerfed. The Baron has two phases for a boss fight which is him dropping grenades so you can't kill him too fast, or in his second, has him have an insta-kill attack with a shockwave. Both of these fights are not designed with co-op in mind and essentially makes it near impossible to get revives as The Beast and the second Baron fight artificially speed the bosses up to catch you to prevent you from reviving, make it a boring experience if somebody is knocked down.

Finally, the gear score system is just a chore and means you need to look for a shirt that does 11 armour for some reason, instead of just being able to level up the stat like before. It's cool that you can still change the cosmetic, but it's just another chore instead of wanting to reward players for killing zombies in a zombie game to level them up, to make them more powerful at killing zombies. They had it basically all correct in the first game, but like the second game, made so many meaningless changes that ruin and take away from the experience, to the point they had to market how much this game was a return to form, which whilst in some elements is, also isn't and it's quite pitiful it's what a lot of the marketing was about. But hey, they sequel bait at the end so maybe there's another chance they can do the same again...

Seeing the endless glaze just feels so hilarious, it's like people are completely blind or just choose to ignore any downsides this game has just because they get to see their favorite Crane once again. Before starting, I want to say that this review is my own experience. I have asked lots of people and they have told me that they enjoyed the game, so don't let my review (or other negative reviews) dissuade you from giving the game a try.

I am so disappointed. I was never really big into the Dying Light franchise, but I enjoyed the first game, and was interested in the second one (Haven't gotten around to finishing it, though). The hype around this game and the way my friends were talking about it made it sound like an amazing entry in the Dying Light franchise.

The tutorial for this game hyped me up to play it. Parkour didn't interest me much, but it's an improvement over the previous two games. Story was interesting enough to keep me engaged, rather than switching off dialogue and playing the game on mute. Combat on the other hand? Weapons feel like paper mache, and zombies take 10 hits to kill, not to mention your stamina drains after 2-3 hits, so you need to back off for a good few seconds for it to regenerate. I didn't want to drop the game immediately, because I was holding out hope that later weapons and skills would rectify me feeling weak. After all, there is a similar feeling in DL1 and 2 where your best options in the beginning are to use environmental traps or stealth to clear zombies.

But then you are forced into a boss fight. The boss itself was 3 attack patterns, repeated over and over, then a "fourth" one added in during the second phase. Also, the boss has a stupidly high amount of health, and can only be attacked briefly. The entire fight felt so tedious and frustrating. The whole fight involved me kiting the boss around the arena to avoid damage (Or take some, because the boss floats over to your location in the middle of attack patterns that I clearly dodged out of the way of?), then attack it in the brief window of time that it is staggered. I died twice before defeating it, and I'm willing to admit that I'm not the greatest at games, but even on my first attempt, I could tell the boss was going to be annoying.

After I cleared that boss, I was hoping those types of bosses would be uncommon, possible reserved to key story events, or that it would be a minute until I fight another boss that is similar. Nope, the story mission right after is another boss fight that involves you kiting a similar zombie around the arena, with slightly different attacks.

I liked the game for what it is as a mindless zombie killer game (more of an expansion pack than a full game experience) but the other aspects of it requires you to suspend disbelief with one huge oversight: the game takes place in what is Switzerland (while they claim it's just a fictional town) and yet half of the NPCs you see are people of color. This is not at all congruent with actual racial demographics of this area of Europe which show that the largest minority groups who are apart of the Swiss area are actually Germans at 8% and then Italians at just 3%. In fact, I don't really think you meet a single Swiss NPC in this game, and most of the white characters, aside from the return of Kyle Crane and the antagonist that fuels the story (unsurprisingly another white guy), are just generic NPCs to fill out space in sanctuary areas. Because the game wanted to invoke that wokeness of making sure that at least 50% of its cast were people of color and also women in power where both major alliable factions are run by a woman, I have to give it a 'not recommended' despite actually receiving the game for free because I made the mistake of purchasing [i]Dying Light 2[/i]'s ultimate edition where The Beast was originally supposed to be a planned DLC that got canceled. 

Techland, being founded in the based country of Poland, should be ashamed for this decision and should perhaps be deported to France or something. Creating a fictional town within a non-fictional country doesn't actually allow you to loophole racial demographics and not even bother to properly represent the native people in their own homeland. That's despicable.

That isn't the only issue with the game, though, as much as it being the most glaring. Techland has also given Kyle Crane the same treatment in his development as protagonist, Aiden, did in DL2. Crane is naive, gullible, and often appears unintelligent and very rash in this expansion pack that continues his story after DL1 where he has apparently been abducted and was the guinea pig to a mad/evil scientist trope character whose team was experimenting on him for apparently thirteen years before he managed to escape. This is also what drives the revenge plot storyline, and so it's another revenge story with a lot of silly, clumsy mistakes in between that just make you groan and roll your eyes as they do their best to make Kyle Crane appear as an absolute buffoon. He seemingly hasn't learned anything from the first game that would make him more of an experienced survivor. He's still getting knocked around, bossed around, made a fool out of as his enemies are always one step ahead of him, betrayed where his response is to essentially just shrug it off instead of recognizing how often he gets betrayed, and just seems very dull and unobservant where his strategy is to just survive on blind luck and keep trying the same thing over and over again until it works. Realistically, he'd have died long ago if not for the plot armor device that he benefits from that the writers continually rely on to tell their story.

To justify this game's existence, they brought back Kyle Crane and allowed him to transform into a "beast" where he can 'hulk' out after accumulating enough damage, receiving enough damage, and dodging incoming attacks. The introductive tutorial to this mechanic was perhaps predictable but still cool nonetheless, but may have simultaneously defanged the power and innate danger of a zombie horde. Of course, to stop you from being too overpowered in the beginning of the game, Crane must first learn how to master and control his new abilities, while wrestling with inner turmoil that he is no longer purely human and is a monster himself. I was very surprised that the first woman you meet, given the rest of the wokeness that exists in this game, is beautifully designed, who no doubt gets the tingles at how strong and masculine Crane is as he stomps around this new area of Europe, making allies and killing these grotesque, mutated abominations now that act as boss fights. She is clearly encouraging his growth as a sort of damsel in distress fantasy where she needs his help to escape to sanctuary. You have to hunt down these creatures, named Chimeras, to inject yourself with their bodily fluids to further empower yourself in your goal for revenge. 

Mostly, I was pleasantly surprised to see that [i]Dying Light: The Beast[/i] was a game that was freely added to my Steam library after not having heard anything about this game's release until a few weeks before. I had thought I was going to have to spend another $70 USD (although this game released for $60 and that price is debatable) to play another game after just spending $70 to be scammed by [i]Borderlands 4[/i]. But there are some bugs, and the parkour, free running and climbing, which is perhaps an integral part of [i]Dying Light[/i]'s identity, is a bit rocky at times. There was a time where I jumped into a body of water and immediately appeared at the very bottom of it and nearly drowned trying to swim to the top, the camera often glitches into surfaces like cliff walls or buildings if you are jumping towards it to grab a ledge, and sometimes the game has trouble figuring out where you want to grab and how to correspond to your movement inputs. The parkour, when it works, is great and you can chain it with wall running to outmaneuver volatiles or any other special infected should you find yourself in a chase.

But, other than receiving it as part of Techland's obligation to the community for both canceling the original DLC but also creating the disappointing sequel that was DL2, I probably wouldn't have purchased this expansion for more than $20 USD, if I decided to purchase it at all given the wokeness apparent. The game is considerably shorter than previous titles and so the $60 price tag cannot be justified. I obtained all of the achievements in around 30 hours of playtime and they are selling this game as though it is a fully fledged AAA experience, which it is far from being considered. People who don't hunt for achievements can probably beat this game in around 15 to 20 hours.

Techland has done well to stick to their zombie killing formula and improve on it since [i]Dead Island[/i], but I don't know if they are any good at telling a compelling story, writing interesting male characters who are not completely flawed and incompetent while they turn female characters into Mary Sue's who the men have to rely upon, etc. It's always really fun to just run around and slice up zombies but that's all there is to the greatness, or lack thereof, that is The Beast. Unfortunately, [i]Dying Light[/i] is probably a gaming franchise that should just conclude with the second game, as I don't trust that Techland can truly resist adhering to pressures to conform to woke ideologues.

To start off, it is a "return to form" but just feels like a jankier version of "The Following". It follows the same formula of RPG elements that DL2 introduced such as leveled weapons and armor, as well as zombies with levels above their head that tank damage like nobodies business. There is really only one city you can actually "parkour" in and it's about the size of someone's backyard. You have to drive to pretty much every location outside of the city and the whole time I am thinking, "Why don't I just play DL1 + The Following again".
Best weapon in the game is the throwing knife, why smack a guy in the head with a level 10 hammer 20 times when one throwing knife to the head one-shots.
Also, goodluck running this game with no DLSS because, just like DL2 or any modern game, it relies entirely on DLSS for optimization to try and get above 60fps on mid-range graphics cards.
While it is a step in the right direction compared to DL2, the price point (Especially considering this was originally supposed to be DLC for DL2) is a bit high to me. Still a fun game I guess, but I am just disappointed.

I got this for free, even then I do wish I didn't receive this at all. This game on release, and still is as im writing this now, awfully optimized. No way to play this game without upscaling to get any FPS above 60 on LOW? I thought DL2 on release with Denuvo was bad but good lord it is horrendous. Aside from the performance, the gameplay; Parkour, combat, beast mode was actually good. Here are some of my feedbacks in regards to Dying Light: The Beast;

I want more dialogue between Crane and [spoiler] Aiden [/spoiler], rather than having Crane say to [spoiler] Aiden [/spoiler] "I have a few questions for you" have him say he needs time alone with [spoiler] Aiden [/spoiler] and have them two talk to each other about their times during DL1 and DL2. Have Crane talk about Harran, his ignorance to the GRE and his attempts at stopping them during DL1. Have him talk about the people he's lost; Jade, Rahim, Brecken, Spike etc. Have him talk about his uncertainty towards the other survivors not knowing that Crane is alive, Spike, Lena, Jasir/Ezgi and everyone else. Have Crane talk about being a test subject for The Baron and losing his will to live and finding some motivation to carry on from Olivia and The Exiles. Have Aiden talk about losing Mia (someone he loved). Have Aiden talk to Crane about what he did in Villedor to help find his sister, being experimented on as a child in X13; Lawan, Frank, Jack Matt, Barney, Sophie, Hakon, Waltz. The monumental struggle of getting to find his sister only to find she's not his sister and losing her after their encounter at X13 and how X13 keeps her alive. Leaving villedor after taking inhibitors, spike mentoring him. Both helping each other on their losses, they're not so different from eachother.

Rather than nerfing Aiden into human mode, have a few missions where you help him to gain control of his beast like powers, the same as Crane did. Have it so that he learns to control it, he becomes more powerful as a result. It feels like after Aiden turns back to human again, he's just nerfed. He is THE BEAST, Crane is a beast but Aiden is THE BEAST, he is the tagline of the game. I understand it is Cranes story, but why include Aiden at that rate.

The sidequests are such a chore, they are to me a 9-5 fetch quest job; Go here, interact with item, kill infected, go back, done. There are two, arguably three sidequests that pose actually interesting questions. The quest A Sign of Love asks the question of; can the people who were infected like the exlies and by extension Crane and Aiden, have children? Don't Look Back in Anger is a quest given to you by Starchild, in which you produce a serum to help the exiles have more motivation to go about their day to day life. Kyle throughout hears an inner voice of his muttering things like "Murderer" and "monster". Towards the end of the quest you enter a trance like state in which Crane is back in the lab but its horrificly set. Blood everywhere, versions of Crane in a cell corner, pacing around in circles, further up Crane can find him strangling people he's met along the way in game and further up still you can see Olivia, as a Viral in the same hallway that Crane saw Jade in, in Dying Light 1. Mentioning Jade if you turn to face behind you, you can see Jade, and next to her you can see Rahim's dead body in the train cart from DL1. At the end of the hallway you find yourself in an arena with your "alters", learning to control the anger and pain to finally use it for good. It asks the question "How do you deal with something this monumental?" Crane took the virus outside the quarantine zone (We know this from DLTB's existence) and by extension, help the GRE end humanity. "Everyones dead because of you" "Animal" "Murderer". It also asks the question of Optimisim vs Desperation. How far is Starchild willing to go to keep people optimistic. These quests alone are the most interesting quests of the entire game.

For the love of god, the zombies need to stop combo'ing the player like its Tekken, it is so frustrating to play against. It is also frustrating to have my windmill attack not work in the middle of a group because I got hit once and I can't activate it again until I stop taking damage from them. It is unrewarding and frustrating.

Beast mode NEEDS to feel like a beast mode. Sure, we get more damage and more executions but even so all it takes is a pack of virals to just overwhelm you and take you down from 100 to 0 in a few hits. I believe beast mode should give you more damage resistance scaled to the players current level irregardless of gear perhaps, or have beast mode include some defensive powers such as a block attack.

Don't get me started on Legendary collectable weapons, what an absolute waste of time. They're not worth collecting (apart from the achievement). The EXPcalibur 2.0 and the Spectral Baseball Bat are perhaps the most horrendous of them all. In the first game, both had the ability to fling zombies comically far. Now, you get WEAPON THROW POWER as in, you throw the weapon with more power. Why? No one asked for that. The only legendary weapons worth getting are the guns; Statement Shotgun, Elite Pistol, Sunray Revolver and the Eraser Rifle. There needs to be more incentive to get these weapons and they must be buffed and less gimicky.

Dear lord, the loot pools. I spent more time getting loot for my blueprints than I did actually using them half the time. Mods and blueprints require lots of wiring and oxidizers and they are so abundent in the recipes that I would need to equip the scavenger gear and run through every dark zone several times just to get all the materials I need. I would end up finding more old world wine than any items I actually needed.

The pacing of the story, honestly what the fuck? It is so jarring and so strange. The first half of the game is very sluggish and very slow to mirror Cranes adjustment to the world. It stays like that until the halfway point in which we meet the exiles. The pace quickens up until the last quarter where it skyrockets exponentially, I still feel the whiplash to this day from it, metaphorically speaking. I would rather us have a few more main missions in between the two halves of the game, perhaps one are two more in each half to not have the pacing be so jarring.

Achievements need to be done PROPERLY. In Dying Light 1 you can track individual amounts of kills or sidequests needed to complete respective achievements but in this game you can't. How do I know that I've killed enough people with the flamethrower, or the car or beast mode? Why are some of the achievements hidden but are infact to do with collectables, main story missions make sense as they might spoil the story but collectables make no sense as you can see what the collectables are from the collectables menu.

The story itself, is flipt from the leaked version of the DLC. Rather than playing as Aiden with Spike looking for Crane, we're doing the opposite. Anyone who's played Dying Light 2 will recognise Aiden right at the start of the game with Crane and Spike, and will also recognise him from being tested on otherwise they wouldn't obscure his face with the monitor at the start of the game. I would much rather there be a blend of the leaked version and the current version compared to what we have now. 

Crane needs to. STOP. FUCKING. MOANING, in my bloody ear EVERY GOD DAMN TIME I go to the inventory screen. Crane definitely is an aggressive nutter and it shows, it's also really off putting.


To conclude; I like that they still have core Dying Light DNA in the game; Parkour is better than DL2 but not as good as DL1, combat (despite its flaws) is still good and beast mode is fun to use. But I can't recommend it in its current state. No end game content really, and nothing being done about the god awful performance is putting me off playing this game more. I'll stick to playing the first one more.
